title: Salmond v Darling: Scottish independence debate on the BBC - as it happened | Politics | The Guardian
summary: most popular tweets from the debate .

text: anyone who thought that the scottish referendum debate would be lacklustre foregone-conclusion may have to reconsider after tonight .

john curtice is probably right to say that tonight 's exchanges wo n't change opinion significantly ( see 11.12pm ) , but the yes camp needed something to lift their morale and feed hopes of a last-minute surge and tonight alex salmond delivered .
here 's the start of tom clark 's story about the guardian 's poll about who won .

alex salmond emerged as the clear winner of the second scottish independence debate , besting alistair darling by a 71 % to 29 % margin , according to an instant guardian/icm poll of scots who had watched the debate .
salmond will be delighted to decisively overturn the verdict in the first round , in which a similar icm poll found alistair darling had won by 56 % to 44 % .

the poll followed an ill-tempered referendum debate in which salmond forced darling onto the back foot on the currency , the nhs and labour 's decision to partner with the conservatives in the better together campaign against independence .
and here 's the start of severin carrell and libby brooks ' story about the debate .

alex salmond accused the former labour chancellor alistair darling of siding with the tories in the campaign against scottish independence in a bloody confrontation in advance of next month 's referendum .

making a concerted fight back in an ill-tempered referendum debate salmond forced darling onto the back foot on the currency , the nhs and labour 's decision to partner with the conservatives in the better together campaign against independence .

salmond repeatedly won applause from vocal yes voters after stating that the referendum in three weeks gave the country the opportunity to take power into scotland 's hands '' , in the debate broadcast live from glasgow across the uk and on the bbc news channel worldwide .
that 's all from me for tonight .
thanks for the comments .
update at 00.14am : earlier i said that there were 15 respondents who said they were voting no pre-debate who afterwards said they would vote yes .
and four people in the yes camp pre-debate shifted to no .
but that was wrong .
i was reading the wrong chart .
it was 7 respondents who said they were voting no pre-debate who afterwards said they would vote yes , and five in the yes camp pre-debate who shifted to no .
sorry about that .

tonight 's debate generated 255,559 tweets , twitter tells me .
icm found that the people who watched the debate divided 51/49 no/yes after it was over when do n't knows were excluded .
but the sample also divided 51/49 no/yes when they were polled before the debate , the icm figures reveal .
on the bbc just now john curtice , the psephologist , said that the last debate did not actually change opinion significantly , and that these figures suggest the same is true of this one .
gregor jackson , an icm research director , has sent us this comment on the poll findings .
following a lacklustre performance in the first debate with alistair darling three weeks ago , alex salmond has struck back with an assured display in the follow-up in glasgow .

not only was he judged to have won by a margin of more than two to one by a sample of 505 people who watched the debate , but he was perceived to have had the more appealing personality and to have had the better arguments .
but there is still all to play for since the debate - in line with the first show - makes little impact on likely voting patterns .
among viewers the vote was split 51 % -49 % in favour of the 'no ' campaign both before and after the debate .

it therefore suggests that the 'yes ' and 'no ' campaigns will need to find other ways of reaching out to the scottish public , particularly undecided voters and waverers , over the next three weeks .
and here are the figures from the poll on voting intention in the referendum .
this is what people said after the debate .
will you vote yes or no ?

( do n't knows included ) ( figures from the last debate in brackets ) yes : 45 % ( 42 % ) no : 47 % ( 47 % do n't know : 8 % ( 11 % ) will you vote yes or now ( do n't knows excluded ) yes : 49 % ( 47 % ) no : 51 % ( 53 % ) remember , this is just a poll of people who watched the debate ( many people wo n't have watched it ) and it is based on a very small sample .
the sample of 500 people polled this time is not the same as last time , although there is almost certainly some overlap .

sorry about that .

who had the better arguments ?
( do n't knows included ) ( figures for last debate in brackets ) salmond : 56 % ( 40 % ) darling : 36 % ( 51 % ) this is a much more important measure than the previous one .
scots are not voting for salmond or darling on 18 september .
they are voting on the basis of rival ideas .
alex salmond easily won on who was most appealing .
who was the more appealing personality ?
( do n't knows included ) ( figures for the last debate in brackets ) salmond : 54 % ( 47 % ) darling : 32 % ( 39 % ) do n't knows : 14 % ( 14 )
proportionally , women were much more likely to say that alex salmond won the debate ( 77 % ) than men ( 63 % ) .
overall , with do n't knows excluded , 71 % of all respondents said salmond won .
( the same factor applied during the last debate , although the numbers involved make these figures statistically quite questionable . )
more from the poll .
only 59 % of those who told icm before the debate that they were voting no thought that darling won .
but 98 % of those who said they were going to vote yes before tonight said salmond won .

my computer crashed for a moment - all that excitement - but i 'm back now .
this has just come through from blair mcdougall , the better together campaign director .
before alex salmond started shouting his way through the debate , viewers would have been left with one message .
alex salmond still ca n't give a credible answer on currency .

while the world was watching he even went as far as to threaten to default on our deb alistair was asking the questions which undecided voters want answered , and was offering what people wanted : more powers without the economic risks that were so obvious tonight .

the alex salmond who shouts his way through first minister 's questions each week turned up , but he could n't move his argument forward because , with two days until we vote , he had no answers to the big question - what currency we would use .
the 72 % of pensioners who said they were worried about their pensions in a poll this weekend are no clearer on what currency their pensions would be paid in .

the women who told the yes campaign 's own poll that the nhs was safer as part of the uk watched alex salmond back-pedal on his scare stories , admitting that the nhs in scotland could not be privatised .
at the end of this debate we 're still where we were at the end of the last one .

tom clark writes : alex salmond emerged as the clear winner of the second scottish independence debate , besting alistair darling by a 71 % to 29 % margin , according to an instant guardian/icm poll of scots who had watched the debate .
salmond will be delighted to decisively overturn the verdict in the first round , in which a similar icm poll found alistair darling had won by 56 % to 44 % .

documents.title: closing statements - snap verdict
text: in the last debate darling faced an awkward moment when he refused to say he agreed with david cameron that scotland could succeed on its own .
in his final statement he seemed to address this ( implying yes ) .
salmond 's final statement was sound , but not scintillating .
darling 's sounded a bit desperate , but a bit more memorable .
it was probably a teeny bit more convincing .
darling says no country this size has achieved so much .
scotland gave the world the age of enlightment .
it could go it alone , he says .
of course he raised the currency again .
but currency is crucial .
scare stories about the nhs are beneath contempt .
salmond says we do n't need to know what plan b is .
but yes we do , he says .
we all have no option but to say politely , firmly , no thanks .

documents.title: closing statements
text: salmond says this is an opportunity .
if scotland votes for independence , it will have great opportunities .
the no team have nothing to offer .
but the one thing yes can offer is that , if scotland votes for independence , scotland will always get the government it votes for .
we do n't need to rise and be a nation again .
we only have to believe in ourselves , salmond says .

documents.title: what happens next - snap verdict
text: a draw , although perhaps salmond sounded a bit more magnanimous .
there are now questions from the audience .
what powers will darling campaign for if scotland votes no , a man asks .
yes are fighting for scotland .
darling and other are fighting for their jobs , a woman says .
darling says the woman has probably made her mind up .
but this is not about him .
this is about children .

documents.title: what happens next
text: q : will people from the yes and no sides be able to work together afterwards ?
darling says he hopes so .
salmond says he thinks it has been an energising campaign .
he thinks turnout will be higher than 80 % .
he agrees with darling about the need for people to work together again .
if he wins , salmond says he will get an all-party group to negotiate independence .
he would like darling to be included .

documents.title: scotland in the world - snap verdict
text: compared to all the other sections , that was relatively inconclusive , although i thought salmond buried the nato point quite effectively .
salmond says lord o'donnell , the former cabinet secretary , said yesterday it was a disgrace there had been no contingency planning for independence .
q : would you compromise on your five-and-a-half your timetable for the removal of nuclear weapons ?
salmond says his timetable is realistic .
the current secretary general of nato is danish .
denmark is a non-nuclear country .
and most nato members are non-nuclear .
it is foolish to say scotland could not join nato .
salmond says trident is not like north sea oil .
north sea oil is a bonus .
how can you say it 's a bonus , darling asks .
scotland would be dependent on it for 15 % of its revenue .

documents.title: scotland in the world
text: q : what would happen to the trident jobs if scotland became independent ?
salmond says there are alternative options ?
darling says jobs would be lost .
q : would you delay the removal of trident ?
salmond says it is ludicrous to have europe 's biggest concentration of nuclear weapons in scotland , and ludicrous to spend £ 100bn on a trident upgrade .
darling says it is foolish to say this , and then propose joining nato , a nuclear alliance .
some 8,000 jobs would go , says darling .
he says he is not prepared to accept that .
he says salmond has not set out any coherent vision of what a scottish defence force would look like .

documents.title: the cross-examination section - snap verdict
text: there 's no doubt after that who would get a job as the next presenter of newsnight .
technically , salmond was good - in fact , excellent .
darling was surprisingly poor on what should be his best subject , the currency , but then salmond took him apart in what was a virtuoso display of forensic duffing-up .
it may be the best moment of the two debates so far ; it was certainly salmond 's best moment .
the weakness is that at this point he was arguing more about david cameron , and the coalition , rather than than preserving the union .
( you can see why salmond was so keen on a debate with cameron . )
but , of course , the two are linked : do you want to be stuck with the tories for another five years ? ''
is one of the yes camp 's best arguments .
salmond is back in the game .

documents.title: salmond questions darling
text: q : how many children are moving into poverty as a result of the coalition reforms ?
too many , says darling .
it 's 100,000 , says salmond .
and 100,000 disabled people would lose out .
yet labour would continue coalition policies .
q : why are you defending conservative policies ?
come on , says darling .
in this campaign salmond is in bed with people he does not normally agree with .
darling says he is a labour politician .
q : is westminster cutting back on funding for scotland ?
darling says salmond can decide how much money is government spends .
salmond says that he is quoting unison .
is that an accurate statement ?
darling says it is for salmond to decide how much he spends .
he accuses salmond of playing games .
q : how much will replacing trident cost ?
darling says he believes in defence .
q : how much ?
over 40 years , about £ 80bn , he says .
q : would n't it be better to spend the money on health ?
darling says he resents that .
he was part of a labour government that increased health spending .
q : name three job creating programmes that scotland would get under further devolution ?
the work programme , says darling .
q : the wages are very low , says salmond .
darling says scotland would get more power over training .
there would be jobs in the financial sector , and universities .
scotland would have more power over welfare .
q : but job-creating powers ?
darling says he has answered .
q : you mentioned a programme that offers poverty wages .
name three job-creation powers ?
being part of the uk gives us the chance to create jobs in the financial services industry .
salmond says poverty will go up .
london would spend £ 80bn on trident .
and scotland , without independence , would have no new job creation powers .

documents.title: darling questions salmond
text: darling asks salmond about the currency , and what his plan b is .
salmond says he has already addressed this .
he did not expect darling to be so unoriginal .
( there is quite a lot of jeering when darling raises this . )
salmond says darling has conceded salmond could use the pound q : what would you do if oil revenues ran out ?
sir donald mckay said there was more oil than others predicted .
salmond says darling predicted oil revenues of £ 6bn in 2011 when he was chancellor .
but it turned out to be £ 11bn .
that 's because i created incentives for investment .
q : what would you do if the revenues fell short ?
salmond says an independent scotland would invest in oil .
q : but what would you do ?
the ifs says there could be a £ 6bn deficit .
salmond says the ifs said an independent scotland could succeed .
darling had a £ 150bn deficit when he was chancellor , he says .
darling says salmond can not answer basic questions .

documents.title: scotland at home - snap verdict
text: this has been salmond 's best section .

the arguments did not always relate particularly well to independence - at times it merged into a debate about coalition policy - but salmond 's critique clearly resonated better with the audience in the hall , and probably with the audience at home too .
q ; the abolition of disability living allowance could lead to 100,000 scots losing money ?
do you support that [ to darling ] ?
darling says no one supports money being taken from people who need it .
but the government has to be able to pay .
why pool the burden of looking about the disabled amongst 5m when you could pool it amongst 60m ?
q : is n't that right [ to salmond ] ?
no , says salmond .
the fact 100,000 people will suffer shows that the pooling argument does n't work .
and darling did not even condemn the cuts to dla .
look at the bedroom tax , he says .
it is a ridiculous argument .
people with disabilities are being penalised .
would n't it be better if we controlled welfare in the first place ?
darling says the bedroom tax is a thoroughly bad idea .
we will repeal it , he says .
you are here as better together , says salmond .
darling says he is a labour politician .
salmond says he has allied with the tories .
q : if we are better together , why are n't we better together already ?
darling says we benefit from the union .
look at uk research funding .
or defence spending , which creates jobs .
if we lose those jobs , that will have a bad effect .
we would be making huge mistake to put that at risk , he says .
salmond says , as first minister , he has been working all week to secure jobs at ferguson 's .
he think the government will be able to sustain employment at that yard .
darling says we have an ageing population in scotland .
he does not want to put that at risk .
that 's why he is against going down a route that will lead to public service being under more pressure .
salmond says the risk to the nhs comes from cuts from westminster .
there are cuts worth £ 25bn on the way .
labour in england warns about more privatisation .
labour in wales say they have had to cut spending .
is darling the only person who does not recognise the threat .
darling says he recognises scaremongering .
salmond says darling is a past master at scaremongering
a woman in the audience says darling is a hypocrite because of his support for nhs privatisation .
if he goes to any more dinners , she says , he will feel the ghost of aneurin bevan on his shoulders .

documents.title: scotland at home
text: q : how would the nhs improve under independence ?
salmond says the nhs would be protected from cuts .
even though the scottish government is in charge of health , there is a knock-on effect from spending cuts in england .
q : why has andy burnham warned about cuts ?
there is an argument in england about the use of the private sector , he says .
but whether money is spent publicly or privately , scotland still gets the fund .

documents.title: economy - snap verdict
text: in the first debate currency was the issue that gave darling his victory .
this time round it was closer , largely because salmond employed two new strategies .

he said he would have a mandate to demand a currency union ; and he repeated a threat raised earlier in the campaign that an independent scotland would force london to pay all uk debt if it did not get a satisfactory outcome .
but darling 's arguments about london having the final say over the scottish economy were decisive ( as they were last week ) , and his point about panama and ecuador was potent too .
people in the audience are making points , and asking questions .
scotland would lose the euro opt-out , a man says .
a woman says there would probably be some kind of currency union .
salmond says he thinks scotland should pay a fair share of the uk 's debts .
countries can not be forced into the euro , he says .
look at sweden .
joining the euro is voluntary .
q : if scotland ca n't have a currency union , what should it do ?
darling says all fall-back positions are unsatisfactory .
q : but scotland could vote yes .
so what should it do in those circumstances ?
darling says all options are unsatisfactory .
q : you accuse salmond of not having plan b .
but you do n't have one either .
darling says , under a currency union , tax and spending decisions would be taken in london , not edinburgh .
q : would you use the pound without formal permission [ to salmond ] ?
salmond says scotland could do that .
but london would deny scotland the assets of the bank of england .
but , if it did that , it would have to pay the whole of the uk 's debt .
the debt run up by alistair darling and his allies .
and that is why it is in london 's interest to pay .
darling says you must have a plan b .
of course we could use the pound , darling say .
ahgh '' , says salmond , seizing on this .
but you would not have a central bank , says darling .
countries that run other people 's currencies , like panama and ecuador , have to run a surplus .
they can not borrow .
that is why it 's a nonsense option .
q : but would london want to face all the uk 's debt ?
darling says if an independent scotland defaulted on its debt , other countries would not lend it money .
salmond says the uk treasury has already said it will accept responsibility for that debt .
but of course it 's scotland 's debt , says darling .
salmond says darling 's acceptance that scotland could use the pound is the most important revelation of the evening .
cathy in the audience asks the second economy question .
q : what currency would scotland use if it were independent ?
salmond says he wants a mandate .
that is crucial .
if he goes into negotiations with a mandate , he will be in a better position .
he has set out other options .
but he will go into negotiations arguing for what 's best .
and that is keeping the pound sterling .
darling says the point about a currency union is both parties have to agree .
look at the euro , he says .
it is a huge risk '' assuming it will fall into place .
a currency union would be a huge risk .
scotland 's decision would be taken in london .
but the question was , what is the alternative .
if its the panama model , he does not want that - using someone else 's bank , with rotten services .
and he does not want the euro either .
darling says he has set out three plan bs for the price of one .
just like buses , he jokes .
if people back his plan , will darling accept that ?
salmond says he will accept a no vote .
will darling accept a yes vote ?
darling says he will accept the outcome .
but he thinks a currency union is a second best option .
he wants sterling .
and that only works if scotland is in the union .
glenn campbell asks the next one .
q : is n't it the case that the obr figures for oil in scotland are too low ?
darling says in the past governments have been too optimistic .
over the last few years revenue from the north sea has been £ 5bn less than expected .
if you lost that in any year , scotland would have to make up for that by raising taxes or cutting spending .
q : are the obr being too pessimistic ?
no .
in the past they have been too optimistic .
look at what sir ian wood .
an independent scotland would get 15 % of its revenue from the north sea .
salmond says in 2010 darling said the obr had become part of the conservative party .
( he used this quote in the first debate . )
darling says that is not right .
salmond asks him not to interrupt .
he says the oil in the north sea is worth £ 1trn .
the tory party and the labour party are the only people in the world arguing that the possession of lots of oil is a curse , not a blessing .
this gets a round of applause .
darling says many of the profits from that go to america .
slowly , the north sea oil is going , he says .
he does not want to take a gamble with the future .
q : do n't you feel it 's a risk [ to salmond ] ?
salmond says oil is 15 % of scotland 's income .
in norway it 's 20 % .
but they are not doing badly .
every other country in europe would give their eye teeth to have north sea oil and gas .
but it 's volatile , darling says .

documents.title: economy
text: alex salmond and alistair darling shake hands before the kelvingrove debate .
j mitchell/getty images a member of the audience asks a question .
q : will we be safe and secure as independent country ?
darling says scotland will be more prosperous as part of the uk .
salmond addresses the currency .
he wants a currency union .
there are other options : an independent currency , or using the pound at a fixed rate .
but he wants the best option for scotland .
a properous scotland keeps the pound sterling , he says .

documents.title: opening statments - snap verdict
text: i listened to the first debate this morning and thought salmond 's opening statement in that one was clearly the best .
but today i thought darling had .
salmond was quite understated , and some of what he said repeated what he said earlier this month .
darling was more precise .
and his good line is not a good answer '' was the most powerful soundbite .
alistair darling says salmond wants independence despite the risk .
salmond wants independence .
darling says he wants a better society .
over the last two years , darling says he has been listening , unlike salmond .
there are no answers , especially on currency .
curency is about jobs and prices and money for public services .
that is the real threat to scotland , he says .
and what about oil .
sir ian wood said the snp were overstating oil supplies are we going to place all our bets on salmond being right .
our children will have to live with this decision .
a good line is not a good answer .

documents.title: opening statements
text: alex salmond goes first .
it is an extraordinary time , he says .
the eyes of the world are focused on scotland .
scotland has been at the crossroads twice before - in 1979 , when thatcher was elected , and in 1997 , when labour was elected and things got better .
the scottish parliament has made life better .

let us do it now .

documents.title: polling figures
text: for background , here is some useful polling data .
the icm polling figures on who won the last debate a guardian blog on the icm data an analysis of the imc figures from john curtice , the psephologist .
here 's an extract .
before they watched the debate 40 % of icm 's sample said that they intended to vote yes , while 46 % indicated that they would vote no .
just 14 % were undecided .
afterwards 42 % said that they would vote yes , 47 % no .
at first glance that looks like the narrowest of advantages for the yes side .
however , the difference is a quirk of rounding error .
in fact the yes tally increased from 40.4 points to 41.6 , and increase of 1.2 that happened to get rounded to an increase of 2 .
meanwhile the no vote rose from 45.7 to 47.3 , a 1.6 increase that only registered as a rise of one point .
while no made net gains amongst previously undecided voters these were cancelled out by some switching from no to yes .
so given also the small numbers involved , the net impact of the debate is best regarded as a draw .

certainly attempts to suggest that the poll showed support for yes had increased from 43 % to 47 % seem to rest on comparing the post-debate figures in this poll ( once do n't knows are excluded ) with the equivalent figure in icm 's last regular poll for scotland on sunday - and not with what the respondents in the instant poll sample had said in advance of the debate .
once the do n't knows are excluded in the instant poll sample the yes tally was 47 % at the beginning of the night and 47 % at the end !
if the debate has indeed proven to be a draw in its impact on voting intentions then both men could be said to have emerged with their honour intact .
trouble is , given they are still ahead in the polls , all that the no said needed was a draw .
yes , in contrast , wanted a decisive win last night - and if this poll is to be believed they did not secure it .

documents.title: timetable for the debate
text: here 's the approximate timetable for the debate .

8.30pm : opening statements from alex salmond and alistair darling 8.35pm : economy section , with questions from the audience 8.50pm : scotland at home section ( ie , welfare , health etc ) , with questions from the audience 9.05pm : scotland and the world , with questions from the audience 9.20pm : what happens after the vote , with questions from the audience 9.35pm : salmond questions darling 9.45pm : darling questions salmond 9.55pm : closing statements

we 've got just under an hour to go before the second debate between alex salmond , scotland 's snp first minister , and alistair darling , the labour former chancellor heading the better together campaign , in the scottish independence referendum .
it is easy to overstate the importance of election debates .
often they do n't make much difference to the outcome and , even if there is a clear winner , that does not always help .
a guardian poll after the first debate showed viewers clearly thought darling won , but since then it 's been the yes camp going up in the polls , not the no camp .
and , in this campaign , as tom clark sets out for the guardian today , there are strong grounds for thinking the no lead is unassailable .

and yet even if there 's only a modest chance of this being the moment that sets scotland on the course to a vote that would break up the united kingdom , it 's got to be worth watching , has n't it ?
the debate starts at 8.30pm .
the bbc are screening it and they have a good preview here .
and here 's a preview from my colleague libby brooks .
here 's how it starts .

alex salmond is expected to launch a sustained attack on monday evening on the conservative-led coalition 's nhs record as he brings one of the key ideological battles of the scottish referendum to the fore in the second televised debate of the campaign .

this second meeting with better together leader alistair darling will be crucial for salmond and the wider yes campaign , after the first minister 's faltering performance in the first debate earlier this month , and as more than 700,000 postal voters - nearly a fifth of scotland 's electorate - will receive their ballots on tuesday .
senior figures in the yes campaign are similarly stepping up their effort to convince voters that only independence can protect scotland from further austerity and privatisation .

in an interview for a forthcoming theguardian.com interactive on the referendum , deputy first ministernicola sturgeon said : people are increasingly seeing the risks to scotland if we do n't vote yes . ''

i 'll be covering the debate as it goes along , providing my analysis as we go along ( it 's only my analysis - you 're welcome to disagree ) , as well as providing reaction and the results of the guardian snap poll .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
